moves.1... f5: Richter responds with a Dutch Defense.
moves.2. d4: Tarrasch attempts to immediately seize the center.
moves.2... e6: Richter guards his KBP and opens a line for his KB.
moves.3... Nf6: Richter counters with his own KN.
moves.4. e3: Opening a line for the KB and preparing for K-side castling.
moves.5... Bb7: Aiming at the future home of Tarrasch's King.
moves.6... Bd6: Aggressive play, aiming at the White KRP.
moves.7. Nc3: Having finished his K-side development, Tarrasch begins bringing out his Q-side pieces.
moves.7... Nc6: Richter's last minor piece comes off the back rank.
moves.8. e4: Bold play by Tarrasch. He feels he has the advantage and wishes to open the game.
moves.8... fxe4: Richter issues a nonverbal challenge: "Bring it on!"
moves.9. Nxe4: Completing the exchange of Pawns and centralizing his Knight.
moves.9... Be7: Richter makes a slight retrenchment in the face of the gathering storm.
moves.10. Ne5: Centralizing his other Knight and opening the diagonal for a potential Q-R5 ch.
moves.10... Nxd4: Unafraid, Richter grabs a loose Pawn and opens up an attack by his fianchettoed Bishop.
moves.11... Bxf6: 11... PxN would have partially blocked in Richter's B, so he chooses the alternative recapture.
moves.12... g6: Interposing, but Tarrasch will break down the barrier.
moves.13. Bxg6+: This sacrifice will force the Black monarch to bestir himself. Richter delays this fate one move...
moves.14. Qxg6+: ...but with this move, he now has no choice.
moves.14... Ke7: 14... K-B1 would be answered with 15 Q-B7 mate, so Richter must move here.
moves.15. Ng4: Tarrasch is relentless in his pursuit of the goal.
moves.15... Qf8: Adding extra protection to the threatened Bishop.
moves.16... Qxf6: Forced, to avoid losing the piece. But now...
moves.17. Bg5: ...this pin appears to be crushing. Richter's Queen is a goner.
moves.17... Ne2+: Never give up! Richter's stunning counterattack swings the game in his favor in a heartbeat.
moves.18... Rxh2+: A beautiful sacrifice. Mate is forthcoming.
moves.20. Bh6: This shortens the game by a move.
moves.20... Qh4#: A superb struggle. Richter, lying on the ropes, came up with a brilliant combination to score the knockout.
